current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To direct the Secretary of Labor to develop a  strategy report to address the skills gap by providing recommendations to increase on-the-job training and apprenticeship opportunities, increase employer participation in education and workforce training, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall develop and submit to

a strategy report to address the skills gap by providing analysis and recommendations to increase on-the-job training and apprenticeship opportunities and increase employer participation in education and workforce training.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall include specific recommendations to achieve the following  goals:

text.#text: The strategy report required by
To increase the aggregate number of employers and employees participating in on-the-job training and apprenticeships.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: can increase employer outreach to encourage new and expanded employer participation in education and workforce training.

text.#text: To determine ways in which the

To identify and prioritize industry-recognized postsecondary credentials that are nationally portable and aligned with in-demand occupations in industries such as construction, manufacturing, and others that are  emerging.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: can better address the skills gap by maximizing existing resources, programs, and personnel.

text.#text: To determine ways in which the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the
shall, at a minimum, include the following:

text.#text: As part of the strategy report under

A comparison of United States on-the-job training and apprenticeship policies and strategies with the policies and strategies of other countries where employers play a larger role in education and workforce training.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: Registered Apprenticeship program to determine how it can be better utilized to appeal to more industries  and to boost the goals described in

text.#text: An assessment of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to refocus or repurpose resources and personnel to better support on-the-job training and apprenticeship goals.

text.#text: An evaluation of any existing or potential opportunities within the
An analysis of the specific barriers preventing the domestic workforce from acquiring the skills desired by domestic employers, including an assessment of opportunities to reduce those barriers by—
improving coordination between Federal agencies that administer employment and training programs; and
modifying Federal employment and training programs to enable States to better utilize Federal employment and training funds.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall include in the skills gap strategy report required under
recommendations for achieving the goals included in the strategy pursuant to
.  Such recommendations may include proposals as follows:

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , State, local and territorial governments, the private sector, universities, industry associations, and other stakeholders to improve policies, coordination, and interaction between such entities, including strategies and best practices to—

text.#text: Actions that may be taken by the Federal Government,
boost public-private partnerships and employer-led partnerships; and
help establish regional industry partnerships.
Adoption of strategies that have been implemented and proven successful  in key industries and regions in the United States and in other countries.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the
, develop plans that identify strategies—

text.#text: In coordination with the
for increased employer participation in career and technical education;
to better align career and technical education curriculums and programs with fast growing industry sectors;
to encourage more pre-apprenticeship and college credit courses in secondary schools;
to improve school-to-work transitions and connections; and
to assist employers in partnering with K–12 schools, community colleges, and service providers.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit to
the strategy report  developed under this section.

text.#text: Not later than 1 year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may implement the recommendations under
as the
determines appropriate, if otherwise permitted under law.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail: refers to the difference, or gap, between the current supply of labor and skills of the workforce and that which is desired by employers.
